div.p: The correct perihelion precession was recently deduced within the frame work of a time varying Gravitational constant G. Here, we deduce also the observed gravitational bending of light and flattening of galactic rotational curves.

In a recent communication[1] we saw that it is possible to account for the precession of the perihelion of Mercury, for example, only in terms of the time varying universal constant of gravitation G. It may be mentioned that Dirac had argued[2] that a time varying G could be reconciled with General Relativity and the perihelion precession by considering a suitable redefinition of units. We will now show that it is also possible to account for the bending of light on the one hand and on the other, the flat galactic rotation curves without invoking dark matter, with the same time variation of G.

It may also be mentioned that some varying G cosmologies have been reviewed by Narlikar and Barrow, while a fluctuational cosmology with the above G variation has been considered by the author [3, 4, 5, 6] and [7].
We start by observing that, as is well known, the bending of light can be deduced in Newtonian theory also, though the amount of bending is half of that predicted by General Relativity[8, 9, 10, 11]. In this case the equations for the orbit of a particle of mass mùëöitalic-mm are used in the limit m‚Üí0‚Üíùëö0italic-m ARROW:to NUMBER:0m\to 0 with due justification. A quick way of obtaining the result is to observe that we have the well known orbital equations[1, 12].

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-e italic-c italic-o italic-s Theta CLOSE:)
\frac{1}{r}=\frac{GM}{L^{2}}(1+ecos\Theta)

div.p: where MùëÄitalic-MM is the mass of the central object, Lùêøitalic-LL is the angular momentum per unit mass, which in our case is b‚Å¢cùëèùëêitalic-b italic-cbc, bùëèitalic-bb being the impact parameter or minimum approach distance of light to the object, and eùëíitalic-ee the eccentricity of the trajectory is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-G POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end

div.p: For the bending of light, if we substitute in (1), r=¬±‚àûùëüplus-or-minusitalic-r RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus ID:infinityr=\pm\infty, and then use (2) we get

semantics.annotation: italic-alpha RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-b italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end
\alpha=\frac{2GM}{bc^{2}}

div.p:
Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha being the deflection or bending of the light. This is half the General Relativistic value.
We also note that the effect of time variation is given by (cf.ref.[1])

semantics.annotation: italic-G RELOP:equals italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-r RELOP:equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:)

div.p:
where t0subscriptùë°0italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{0} is the present age of the universe and tùë°italic-tt is the time elapsed from the present epoch.
Using (4) the well known equation for the trajectory is given by (Cf.[13],[12],[14])

semantics.annotation: italic-u " ADDOP:plus italic-u RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-u FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
u"+u=\frac{GM}{L^{2}}+u\frac{t}{t_{0}}+0\left(\frac{t}{t_{0}}\right)^{2}

div.p:
where u=1rùë¢1ùëüitalic-u RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:endu=\frac{1}{r} and primes denote differenciation with respect to ŒòŒòTheta\Theta.
The first term on the right hand side represents the Newtonian contribution while the remaining terms are the contributions due to (4). The solution of (5) is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-u RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-e italic-c italic-o italic-s OPEN:{ OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) Theta ADDOP:plus italic-omega CLOSE:} CLOSE:]
u=\frac{GM}{L^{2}}\left[1+ecos\left\{\left(1-\frac{t}{2t_{0}}\right)\Theta+% \omega\right\}\right]

div.p: where œâùúîitalic-omega\omega is a constant of integration. Corresponding to -‚àû<r<‚àûùëüADDOP:minus ID:infinity RELOP:less-than italic-r RELOP:less-than ID:infinity-\infty<r<\infty in the Newtonian case we have in the present case, -t0<t<t0subscriptùë°0ùë°subscriptùë°0ADDOP:minus italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-t RELOP:less-than italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end-t_{0}<t<t_{0}, where t0subscriptùë°0italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{0} is large and infinite for practical purposes. Accordingly the analogue of the reception of light for the observer, viz., r=+‚àûùëüitalic-r RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus ID:infinityr=+\infty in the Newtonian case is obtained by taking t=t0ùë°subscriptùë°0italic-t RELOP:equals italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt=t_{0} in (6) which gives

semantics.annotation: italic-u RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-e italic-c italic-o italic-s OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Theta ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega CLOSE:)
u=\frac{GM}{L^{2}}+ecos\left(\frac{\Theta}{2}+\omega\right)

div.p: Comparison of (7) with the Newtonian solution obtained by neglecting terms ‚àºt/t0similar-toabsentùë°subscriptùë°0RELOP:similar-to italic-t MULOP:divide italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim t/t_{0} in equations (4),(5) and (6) shows that the Newtonian ŒòŒòTheta\Theta is replaced by Œò2Œò2FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Theta ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end\frac{\Theta}{2}, whence the deflection obtained by equating the left side of (6) or (7) to zero, is

semantics.annotation: italic-c italic-o italic-s Theta OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-e ARG:end
cos\Theta\left(1-\frac{t}{2t_{0}}\right)=-\frac{1}{e}

div.p: where eùëíitalic-ee is given by (2). The value of the deflection from (8) is twice the Newtonian deflection given by (3). That is the deflection Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha is now given not by (3) but by

semantics.annotation: italic-alpha RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-b italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end PUNCT:,
\alpha=\frac{4GM}{bc^{2}},

div.p: which is the correct General Relativistic Formula.

The problem of galactic rotational curves is well known (cf.ref.[8]). We would expect, on the basis of straightforward dynamics that the rotational velocities at the edges of galaxies would fall off according to

semantics.annotation: italic-v POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end
v^{2}\approx\frac{GM}{r}

div.p: whereas it is found that the velocities tend to a constant value,

semantics.annotation: italic-v RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:300 italic-k italic-m MULOP:divide italic-s italic-e italic-c
v\sim 300km/sec

div.p:
This has lead to the hypothesis of as yet undetected dark matter, that is that the galaxies are more massive than their visible material content indicates.
We observe that from (4) it can be easily deduced that

semantics.annotation: italic-a RELOP:equivalent-to OPEN:( OVERACCENT:ddot ARG:start italic-r ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:ddot ARG:start italic-r ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end OPEN:( italic-t OVERACCENT:ddot ARG:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-r ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end
a\equiv(\ddot{r}_{o}-\ddot{r})\approx\frac{1}{t_{o}}(t\ddot{r_{o}}+2\dot{r}_{o% })\approx-2\frac{r_{o}}{t^{2}_{o}}

div.p:
as we are considering infinitesimal intervals tùë°italic-tt and nearly circular orbits. Equation (11) shows (Cf.ref[1] also) that there is an anomalous inward acceleration, as if there is an extra attractive force, or an additional central mass.
So,

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m italic-r ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m italic-v POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end
\frac{GMm}{r^{2}}+\frac{2mr}{t^{2}_{o}}\approx\frac{mv^{2}}{r}

italic-v RELOP:approximately-equals OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-G italic-M ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
v\approx\left(\frac{2r^{2}}{t^{2}_{o}}+\frac{GM}{r}\right)^{1/2}

div.p:
From (13) it is easily seen that at distances within the edge of a typical galaxy, that is r<1023‚Å¢c‚Å¢m‚Å¢sùëüsuperscript1023ùëêùëöùë†italic-r RELOP:less-than NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m italic-sr<10^{23}cms the equation (9) holds but as we reach the edge and beyond, that is for r‚â•1024‚Å¢c‚Å¢m‚Å¢sùëüsuperscript1024ùëêùëöùë†italic-r RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m italic-sr\geq 10^{24}cms we have v‚àº107‚Å¢c‚Å¢m‚Å¢ssimilar-toùë£superscript107ùëêùëöùë†italic-v RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m italic-sv\sim 10^{7}cms per second, in agreement with (10).
Thus the time variation of G given in equation (4) explains observation without taking recourse to dark matter.

J.V. Narlikar, ‚ÄùIntroduction to Cosmology‚Äù, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1993.
D.R. Brill and D. Goel, Am.J.Phys. 67(4), 1999, 317.

P.G. Bergmann, ‚ÄùIntroduction to the Theory of Relativity‚Äù, Prentice-Hall (New Delhi), 1969, p248ff.
